content.text: The student places the metre ruler on the pivot. She places a load P on the metre ruler at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. She adjusts the position of the metre ruler on the pivot so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced
The ruler balances with the pivot at the \(75.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Calculate the distance \(a\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot
Record the value of \(a\) in the first row of Table 1.1
She records, in Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) from the pivot to the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the metre ruler

She repeats the procedure placing the load P at the \(85.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(80.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(75.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(70.0 \text{cm}\) mark. She records the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in Table 1.1
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
G =
The weight \(W\) of the metre ruler is numerically equal to \(2\mathrm{G}\)
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the metre ruler
W =
Suggest one practical reason why it is difficult to obtain accurate readings for \(a\) and \(b\)
Using only the apparatus provided for the experiment, explain briefly how you would determine the position of the centre of mass of the metre ruler
A student determines the weight of a metre ruler using a balancing method
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up
Write down the current \(I\) shown on the student's ammeter
Record the potential difference \(V\) shown on the student's voltmeter in the first row of Table 2.1
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(20.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire
Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 2.1, \(\frac{R}{l}\) for \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
The student places a sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\)
He measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across length \(l\) of the resistance wire. He measures the current \(I\) in the circuit
The meters are shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3
Write a conclusion about the relationship between \(R\) and \(l\)
Justify your conclusion by reference to the results
The student repeats the procedure using \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\). The readings and results are shown in Table 2.1
Look carefully at the values of \(\frac{R}{l}\) in Table 2.1

parts.label: (c)

content.text: Use the values in Table 2.1 to estimate the resistance \(R_{2}\) of \(2.000 \text{m}\) of the resistance wire
Show your working

content.text: A student investigates the resistance of a resistance wire
Fig. 2.1 shows the circuit that he uses
On Fig. 3.2, measure the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object
\(h_{\mathrm{O}} =\)
On Fig. 3.1 measure the distance \(u\)
The actual object distance \(U\) is \(20.0 \text{cm}\)
The student places the lens at the distance \(U = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
He moves the screen slowly until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
He measures the distance \(V\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. On Fig. 3.1, this distance is represented to scale by the distance \(v\)
Use Fig. 3.1 to determine the actual distance \(V\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. Show your working
V =
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the magnification \(m\) using the equation \(m = \frac{V}{\dot{U}}\).
The student measures the height of the image \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) that is formed on the screen. The reading is shown in Table 3.1
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the ratio \(\frac{h_{\mathrm{I}}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\)
Fig. 3.1 is drawn to \(1 / 10^{\text{th}}\) scale
State whether the results agree with the suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to the results
statement
justification
Suggest how you would continue to use the same apparatus to test the suggestion that the magnification \(m\) is equal to the ratio \(\frac{h_{\mathrm{I}}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\)
The student repeats the procedure using \(U = 30.0 \text{cm}\). The readings and results are shown in Table 3.1
Another student suggests that the magnification \(m\) is equal to the ratio \(\frac{h_{\mathrm{I}}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\)
A student investigates the magnification of the image produced by a lens
Fig. 3.1 shows the set-up
Fig. 3.2
A student investigates the time taken for water to evaporate to dryness when heated from above
Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up. The power of the heater is constant
The following is also available:
supply of water at room temperature
metre ruler
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the time taken for the water to evaporate
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions
You should:
state any additional apparatus required
explain briefly how you would do the investigation
state the key variables that you would keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
